name: N-(1-acetyl-1H-pyrazolo[3,4-b]pyridin-3-yl)acetamide
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1870

name: N-(1-acetyl-1H-pyrazolo[3,4-b]pyridin-3-yl)acetamide
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1870
Reason: The target compound consists of a pyrazolopyridine core with two acetyl groups, and an amide linkage. The basic pyridine unit has a melting point of about 115 degrees Celsius. Each acetyl group is likely to raise the melting point due to increased molecular weight and rigidity of the structure. The amide linkage will also increase the melting point because of the possibility of hydrogen bonding, which increases the intermolecular forces. The pyrazole ring fused with the pyridine also raises the melting point through added rigidity and nitrogen's ability to participate in hydrogen bonding. Based on these considerations, the acetyl groups could each contribute an estimated increase of about 20-30 degrees Celsius, and the amide linkage might add around 25-35 degrees Celsius by enabling additional hydrogen bonding. The fused ring system adds more complexity and rigidity, potentially contributing an additional 30-40 degrees Celsius.
Prediction: The melting point is predicted to be the sum of the basic pyridine unit's melting point plus the increments due to the functional group effects. This yields approximately 115 + (2*25) for the acetyl groups + 30 for the amide linkage + 35 for the fused ring system, totaling a predicted melting point of approximately 115 + 50 + 30 + 35 = 230 degrees Celsius.
